Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2013 04:36AM marie5890 wrote: CONGRATS PAIGE!!!!!  A radial scar is a B9 condition that very much can look like cancer on a mammo. So much so that the ladies who come here with a BIRAD5, most do come back positive for cancer (stats say 95% of BIRAD5 end up as cancer), but the few that haven't end up being Dx-ed with a radial scar, with one exception that I can remember (that being fat necrosis). Usually, when a radial scar is seen on a mammo, it's not the microcals that are raising a red flag, but rather the whole look (Spiculated, non-smooth edging etc)…Considering how this radiology disagreed with the other radiologist on how to describe the calcs, that would make sense… Getting a radial scar removed is a wise idea.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2013 02:55PM marie5890 wrote: What radiologists are looking for when it comes to microcals… What they are looking for if a woman has been given a BIRADS3 (i.e. retest in a 3 or 6 months time frame) is to see 1)if there is an increase the the number and 2)what kinds of formation it is presenting. Observations like "tightly clustered" or "linear" are flag of concern that will have a radiologist rating it a BIRAD 4 (basically meaning, a biopsy is warranted) Does this mean it definitely is cancer? No, but it could also very well be. It IS a flag of concern. (In my layperson's experience here, it's like a orange flag of concern, not red. But definitely a flag. Thus, the need for a biopsy Also what I have observed when women have come with these kinds of scenarios and it does come back positive for cancer, it IS very early stage. Many times not even invasive (known as DCIS or LCIS, depending on the kind). Some may have small areas of micro invasion of IDC. Praying you all get B9 results. However, know that if you don't, your cancer got caught very early. Very early. It's one of the big reasons why women should get an annual mammo after the age of 40. So it's caught very early… Praying for you all. (oh also, either a radiologist or a breast surgeon will do the biopsy most likely. Both are qualified, both are doctors. How you get the results and from whom can vary due to the policies of where you are going and who you are working with)

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 05:53PM marie5890 wrote: I did a some checking for you and found this. I bolded the area that does say that it can be caused by benign conditions. Hang in there! http://www.uptodate.com/contents/nipple-inversion The nipple is the central projection in the areola. When the nipple is pulled in and points inward instead of out, it is termed nipple inversion or retraction. Nipple inversion can affect one breast or both, and can be congenital or acquired. Acquired nipple inversion can be due to benign or malignant causes. Benign nipple inversion is usually a gradual process, occurring over a few years. When nipple inversion occurs rapidly, the underlying cause can be inflammation, postsurgical changes, or an underlying malignancy [1

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 06:46PM marie5890 wrote: Dont let it scare you. It's her specialty. She should be fascinated if she hasnt come to a definitive answer. It's what has made her "best surgeon". She is taking good care of you by being thourough. She wants to be absolutely sure. The fact that the MRI was inconclusive is a very good thing. MRI's show blood flow, both the pick up and the wash out. Cancer needs blood flow. One of the major draw backs of MRI's is that they are overly sensitive and pick up EVERYTHING. They have a high rate of false positives. That fact that it didnt pick up anything that concerned or alarmed her right of the bat is a very very GOOD thing. From all that you have posted, the more it's looking B9 from my layperson's understanding. It's not screaming "CANCER". But she is being a great Dr and is wanting to get to the bottom of the situation. You are being well cared for. :)

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 07:56AM marie5890 wrote: In all of my research and understanding this is what I have found. I have heard of cancerous masses, when they are removed and fully biopsied, can have incidental elements of PASH and other B9 conditions. When it comes to the reverse this is what I have come to understand. When who have been Dx-ed with ADH or ALH (both which put a woman at increased risk of cancer; some experts think is can be  step before cancer cell development), when those ladies have had lumpectomies, areas of DCIS (associated with ADH) or LCIS (associated with ALH) have been found. Both DCIS and LCIS are Stage 0 breast cancer. Meaning they are non-invasive forms. I have never heard of a woman who has PASH (which is what I have) and had it removed end up having cancer found with it. And I have done extensive research on PASH since that is my Dx. The thing with PASH is that is can grown back. Even when it's removed, it can grow back. It can also disappear on it's own. The protocal for dealing with PASH is to have it removed. I chose not to, and my breast surgeon was in agreement.

So start researching things like grade and staging, start researching hormonal receptors and how that figures into treatment. Start educating yourself on the variety of options for mastecotomies. Stare breast cancer in the face and go "Ok what if I do have breast cancer. What I am going to do. How am I going to fight this." That way, if it does come back cancer, you are emotionally prepared. If it comes back that you are fine, you have reason to rejoice! :) I do think that the advice you have gotten about talking to your Dr is a good one.

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2012 01:50PM marie5890 wrote: Hello MrsKn and welcome. First bit of advice. Stop with Dr Google. You simply dont know what you are dealig with and at this point you really dont even have enough information to be googling about. There are all kinds of conditions that can affect the breast that are *not* breast cancer. That is what the biopsy results will show. Exactly *what* is *what* going on with your breast. Since this was your first mammo, they dont have a baseline one to compare it to. THIS was your baseline. So they are beign cautious, which is good. Can we tell you if you should be worried or if it's just nothing? Not really, one way or the other. Should you be worried? Not necessarily. Is it going to be "nothing". Possibly so. Factually and medically speaking, it's really hard to tell. Most biopsies (up to 80%) come back B9 (benign). So the odds  are on your side.   But no one can say definitively. Only the results of a biopsy can ultimately do that. Hang in there. The waiting is a bitch. That is a fact, too.

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2015 03:46PM marie5890 wrote: Ok Deep breath. With a BIRADS 5, more likely thank not, you will be getting a cancer Dx. On occasion, a BIRADS5 comes back b9, but that is not typical. SO, with that in mind, a few things. 1)"breast cancer" is an umbrella term that cover a whole host of different kinds of cancer that can affect the breast. I think there is about 22 different kinds. With that in mind, it will take some time for *your* cancer picture to come into view. 2) In the "Just Diagnosed" forum there are a couple of thread that can be helpful to you as you get your ducks in a row, while you *wait* to know exactly what you are dealing with One is at the top of that forum put up by the Moderators with links. Another is entitled "Just Diagnosed--Get Prepared". In there you will find some practical advice from what others have learned was helpful them in the initial stages. 3) Please stay away from Dr Google. a) he is not a doctor b) a lot of what is out there is dated c) again, there are all kinds of cancer that can affect the breast and you don't know exactly what you are dealing with yet 4) Keep up with the xanax. Even women who normally don't reach for pharmicutial help found that, in the initial stages of their Dx, they needed some sort of anti-anxiety meds to help keep their head and heart quiet. There is going to be a lot of information coming your way. You need to keep your head as quiet and clear as you can while you make your decisions. 5)This webstie is a great place for information. With that said, I always advise ladies to stay within those forums and threads that best reflects to what they know about their situation. For example, right now I would say stick to the "Just Diagnosed" forum. Later, go to the "Treatment" sections, etc. As you find out what kind of cancer you have (i.e. ER? PR? Her2? ) etc, there are forums for that. Hang tight. Keep breathing. Based on the preliminary look of it being 1.1 cm , that would put you in Stage 1 (very early stage). A more accurate determination will come later, but hang on to that. What is seen is small.

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2013 11:30AM marie5890 wrote: Because you are full of fear I suggest you talk to your Dr.  Fear is an awful thing to wade thru, and since all you have is pain, an no other symptoms, try not to panic.  This is the really toxic side of all "breast awareness" education that we have been exposed to. Many of us here call  it "pinkwashing" When have heard soooooooooo much about breast cancer, that when something goes wrong with our breasts, it's the first thing we think of. And for you since your mother died of BC, it's even all the more magnified. But the reality that are TONS of things that can happen to our breasts that have nothing, nada, zip, zippo, to do with breast cancer.  But we are so pinkwashed, the fear sets in the moment there is something "different" What you really need to do is to have a good sit down with your Dr and talk about this. Express your concerns, your fears.  Would the BRCA testing help because of your mother? Not necessarily. It's when a woman's family history is heavy with BC and/or Ovarian cancer is suspected that it's look to. That means, mother, sisters, aunts, etc. More than just one relative. The two biggest risk factors for getting BC are these. Being female and getting older.  I hope you call your Dr and can have a productive conservation. I think that would help you the most.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2011 07:45PM - edited Jun 18, 2011 07:47PM by marie5890 Tildymom, Firs of all, there is some disagreement within the BC community and professionals about DCIS. Is it cancer, some say yes, some say no. Sometimes in does because invasive, sometimes it doesnt. So your confusion there really is just reflecting the confusion that even the experts argue over about it. AFA as clusters. Yes, it's the clustering of microcalcifications (not macrocalcifications), that is a "yellow flag" of something possibly be suspicious. If they are not clusters, it's not really alarming. If I recall correctly from my past research, it's the idea that the clusters could possibly being signally necrosis (the dying of cells). Something like that. I want to see if I can find one of Beesie's posts to help clarify (she is a poster here who has done extensive research as a laywoman with DCIS into it)  Ok here is one It's in the DCIS forum and it's entitled "DCIS facts and misinformation" community.breastcancer.org/for...

No. However, based on their experience, they can't say what they are seeing definitely *not* early stage. SO the wisest course of action, is for you to have a biopsy. Chances are still, it's B9. They are just making sure, thru putting tissue samples under a microscope, exactly what it is. 1) there really is no need to go the full blown panic mode. 2) if on the outside chance it is cancer, it has been caught EXTREMELY EARLY. Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2013 05:39PM marie5890 wrote: Nora, No, just because a woman has microcals, it doesn't mean they will turn into cancer. Most microcals are harmless and mean nothing. They are very common. What is significant about some microcals is that *can* be a signal that cancer is present. That is why, depending on how they appear, a woman is sent for a biopsy. And even then, most of those biopsies come back B9 So please understand, just because you have microcals it does NOT mean that somewhere down the road you will have cancer. That is a myth. Hang in there!

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2011 07:31AM - edited Aug 25, 2011 07:32AM by marie5890 You have the choice of having it removed if it is B9. Many women have B9 lumps removed for peace of mind.  I chose not to do anything with mine. Both myself and the BS was fine with that as surgery would pose other possible problems for me. Core biopsy is a normal recommendation. The idea of spreading cancer cells due to biopsy is an e.x.t.r.e.m.e.l.y. E.X.T.R.E.M.E.L.Y. rare, very rare possibility. Very rare very rare. My biopsy was stereotatic. So imaged guided (my tumor is not palpable and deep inside near the chest wall.) You are numbed up so there is little discomfort was my experience. Since your (if I recall correctly) is closer to the surface it really shouldnt be a problem. It's when it's image guided that it gets more complex because of all the imagine equipment.  Can your husband be with you? Mmm not sure. Are you having it done in the Dr office? Or other place. I know there was no way they were going to let anyone in the procedure room when I had mine done. My experiencing watching the ladies here is that inconclusive results are not common. If there is any question what they do is send the sample to another facility to have another pathologist look at it.

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2017 02:37PM marie5890 wrote: Hope this helps in your understanding of radial scars.  Hope you find it helpful in terms of education.  A radial scar is a benign hyperplastic proliferative disease of the breast. Proposed possible causes include localized inflammatory reaction and chronic ischemia with subsequent slow infarction. Histopathologically radial scars contain hyperplastic tissue cells and a central fibrous core, with radial extension of tubular structures (the spiculated peripheral borders), mimicking infiltrating carcinoma. This tubular formation has two rows of cells, epithelial and myoepithelial 9-10. The malignant potential is two times greater than in the normal population without radial scar 11-12.   (and to go back to post that 'Leaf' posted in this thread back in Aug of 2009) Be very, very, very careful about statistics. As Mark Twain said, "There are lies, damn lies, and statistics." There is controversy about how much risk a radial scar portrays, but in this paper they get a relative risk of almost 2. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18297395 What is relative risk? www.breastcancer.org/risk/unde... When they say 'double your risk' it does NOT NOT NOT mean 2 x the lifetime risk of the average woman (in the US) = 2 x 12 % = 24%. When they say 'double the risk' they mean double the risk of the woman WITHOUT any particular risk factors. (The average woman in the US has some risk factors.) The figures I've seen tossed about for this 'base' risk factor is about 3-5%, so double that risk would mean a lifetime risk of about 6-10%. These are estimates, of course.  (Marie here: about risk factors. Concerned it's important to remember that the 2 biggest risks that ALL women have are a)being a woman and b) getting older. Those are THE biggest factors in getting BC)

Posts.Content: May 16, 2016 06:04PM marie5890 wrote: Hi SS and welcome. Completely understand why you are so scared, but it's most likely not as bad as your imagination is making you think it is. First of all, take some deep breathes. Take several Do you have a copy of your report? If so, can you please post it? That would help us give you an idea why the radiologist is recommending a biopsy. With that said, if the area was screaming cancer, you would have a BIRAD5, not a BIRAD4. 80% of BIRAD4 comes back B9. Remember that. With the very little information you have shared, it sounds like they are recommending a biopsy because of the increase of microcals. Microcals are NOT cancer, but what they can do is raise a flag of pre-cancer or very very early stage (knowns as DCIS, a NON-invasive very early cancer) SO take some more deep breathes. Post the report if you have it. DONT DO ANY RESEARCH until you get your results back from your biopsy (get a copy of that report, too)

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 01:04PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Brandy. Welcome. I have been thru an MRI so I can give you an idea. The medium to rapid enhancement is a way of describing the blood flow to these nodules. The contrast dye that you were given shows how quickly (or not quickly) the nodes are getting blood to them. Many cancers needs blood to grow. Now it's important to know that MRI's are notorious for picking up everything, and that includes things that are not cancer. There are other conditions which will also have blood flow to them that would show medium to rapid enhancement Because of the blood flow (medium to rapid enhancement) they are doing the prudent thing sending you to a breast surgeon. Most likely you will have some sort of biopsy done.  ***PLEASE NOTE THIS***** In no way am I saying you have cancer. Even your MRI isnt saying that. What is being said, there are some areas of concerns that need to checked out. Try your best not to panic. They are being prudent. They want to make sure exactly what is going on. You are getting good care.
Posts.Title: Worried and a little scared blweber2 brendaks

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2011 02:47PM marie5890 wrote: The "persistent enhancement on the delayed phrase" is something that should give you a reason to exhale a bit. If that delayed phrase showed a "washout", it would be a reason to be a bit more concerned. *****AGAIN***** I am not saying one way or the other if it's malignant or not. Only a biopsy can ultimately show that. What I am saying is that, many cancers have a certain way of reacting to the contrast dye on an MRI when it comes to blood flow. "medium to rapid enhancement" is a flag of concern...."persistent enhancement on the delayed phase" makes that flag of concern more yellow than red, so to speak. You do have a flag of concern, but it's not screaming cancer. And yes, there things that can show up on mammo's/US's and MRI's that "scream" cancer. Yours is not, but it is saying "Something is here that does need to be further checked by biopsy". So, hold on to that. Breathe deeply if you need to. We will be waiting here with you. BTW, how is your son doing? Hope surgery went well.

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2012 12:10PM marie5890 wrote: Hello worried. You asked "did they see something that would suggest cancer?" The answer is--not necessarily. Is it a good sign that they are waiting a week?---Dont read anything into that, one way or the other. A week really isnt considered "long" to be honest in terms of most cancers. Know this...Most biopsies (up to 80%) come back B9. You have cautious doctors looking after your wife. That is good. That is better than having doctors let her fall thru the cracks. Get the tissue under a microscope. Find out exactly what *it* is.

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2016 05:04PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Boyd. Ultimately, the results of biospies is the gold standard, not just how things look on imaging. (IE mammo/US/MRI etc). It's also important to remember that a radiologist is a doctor with their specialty in those procedures that have to do with imaging. Based on what you have posted, she is concerned on how the lymph nodes look now based on how they have looked in the past. That is significant, and should not be overlooked. It sounds like to me, based on what you have posted, she wants to get the pathology report back on the this biopsy first, and then deal with the lymph node changes. (IE one step at a time). It sounds like you are in very good hands that that she is not going to let you fall thru the cracks and that she wants to make sure that definitive answers are found to explain the changes she is seeing on the imaging. If you are wondering "are the other reasons beside cancer that can explain the changes in lymph nodes?". The answer is yes. Infection being one. So take slow deep breaths. You don't have any solid answers yet. Only a biopsy can do that. You have a Dr there who is making sure solid answers are found.

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2016 04:39AM marie5890 wrote: One thing that can cause microcals is injury. And they can be found anywhere. That your microcals are in "cluster and linear form" is something of an "orange flag", meaning its a bit more concerning over there being microcals that are more scattered in appearance. When they are like this, based on what I have learned and seen women come thru here with similar, it is possible that DCIS is present. It's a non-invasive form of cancer and basically the earliest stage (Stage 0 , I believe is the classification.) You may want to read up on that. DCIS (Ductal carcinoma In Situ). You may also what to read up on terms such as "Grade", "Stage" "Form". Again, biopsy is the gold standard so only that can tell you. **IF** it comes back positive for DCIS, know this. It may take a bit more time for what YOU are dealing with to come into view. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a whole host of different cancerS that can effect the breast. Pure DCIS is normally treated surgically and often times with radiation, but not chemo, since it is not invasive (IE it has not invaded the breast tissue and is contained the the ducts)

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2017 07:32AM - edited Feb 1, 2017 07:34AM by marie5890 HI Admomma and welcome. Im surprised they even bothered with a mammo since you are only 29. Mammos tend not to be good imaging techniques for someone your age because younger breast tissue is more dense, making mammo's not very useful. However since your clinical signs are so clearly obvious it could be that it did show something. That said, with the way you describe your breast and the "caving in" look and retracted nipple, something IS going on. And no radiologist can look at a film and say it's "fat necrosis"...only a biopsy can tell you that. Go for the MRI and then get copies of all the reports, including the mammo, and post the results here, and we can help you understand what is being said. Don't be surprised if you are sent for a biopsy. Agains something is going on with your breast, and it's important you find out what One step at a time. You need to find out definitive answers as to why this is happening to your breast. (AFA as double Mx to "just get rid of them", having a mastectomy comes with it's own set of problems and complications, so you don't want to that. Besides, if you do have cancer, and your clinical signs are troubling to be sure, having an Mx most likely won't be enough.

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2017 06:01PM - edited Feb 13, 2017 06:10PM by marie5890 Jules, have you explored other reasons for your breast pain? Are you going thru menopause? Hormonal fluctuations can cause breast pain. I know that is happening to me right now. Im 52. Diet can also be a contributing factor.  Breast pain here a link. What do your reports say as to the degree of density in your breasts? In some states, like mine of CT, if a radiologist reports that a woman has extremely dense breasts in their reports, then insurance can't deny an MRI. There is an actual grading system of density. Do you have the actual copies of your reports? If not, I would get them. Another option would be to see a second opinion and see what they say.  Another link explaining breast pain

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 08:16AM marie5890 wrote: Nellie, Hello and welcome. Having it removed is most definitely something you can request, regardless if it's B9 or not (obviously it's coming out if not). Try your best not to panic with your dr saying "its suspicious". There is an spectrum of what "suspcious" means when it comes to what a radiologist says. That may simply mean that they, based on their training, cant say with 100% confidenence what exactly it is. So a biopsy is needed. 80% of biopsies come back B9. If you would like, if you chose to get a copy of the radiologist's report (it's your legal right to have a copy if you want one), some of us here can help you better understand what the concern is in more layman's terms. Even then, though, we cant tell you for sure if it's cancer or not. Only a biopsy can. These reports, to put it in a more simplistic way, can give you and indication of is it a more yellow flag of concern or is it a red flag of concern.

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 01:37PM - edited Apr 15, 2012 01:41PM by marie5890 Hi Ann, I can give you my perspective as one of those women you are referring to. I find it a way of helping those who are bound up in the fear and anxiety of a possible Dx, since I know what that is like. I also see it as a way of  being a sentinal for those of you who are fighting it. I get the impression that many women who are fighting it may not have the patience of dealing with the fear, and sometimes irrational fears, of those who have are going thru the diagnostic process. But to be fair, I have been a paraplegic for 40 years so I know how to deal with people who are fearful of various medical conditions. I tend not to get wrapped up in their fears, but can be of assistance in some ways. Some people are hardwired to be fearful, anxious. I can see why it would not be helpful to them to hang out on a cancer board. But I am not hardwired that way.   I think of it as being the "receptionist" that you first meet when you walk into a Dr office. A friendly face and smile of re-assurance that you are in good hands and that people care...

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 08:49AM marie5890 wrote: Hang in there Ipost.  Not having kids and being 38 doesnt raise your risk as much as you think. Most women who have BC are mothers and have breast fed.  Your mother having had BC does give you a bit more of a risk, but unless you are BRCA1 or 2 positive, even that doesnt go up too much Dont read too much into the Dr's reaction or being sent for a mammo/US. Even those and the radiologist cant really Dx BC thru that. Only a biopsy can and most breast biopies (80%) come back B9. Having a lump doesnt mean breast cancer. Having a mammo, US, MRI done doesnt mean one has breast cancer. Even getting a biopsy doesnt mean a woman has breast cancer. What it does mean is that "something" is there, and it's prudent to find out what "it" is. And most of the time "it" is NOT breast cancer. Good Luck

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2012 11:00AM marie5890 wrote: jheat, Hello and welcome. It's completely understandable that you are going crazy. We have had it drilled into our head that "if you find a lump get it checked out". What we arent taught is that most lumps are not cancer. And it doesnt help when people, well meaning as they are, say "you will be fine". No one knows at this point what the lump is. It cant be known by imagining alone (mammos, ultra sounds etc) exactly what it is but it can give some insight, so dont be surprised if they ask for a biopsy. You said it's at the 10 oclock position and 3cm x1 cm. Does that mean you have had a mammo or US done? Do you have a copy of the radiologist report? If so, some of us can help you wade thru some of the medical-ese and give you an idea of what is being seen. At this point it's really hard to know anything other than there is a lump and the doctors what to find out exacly what it is. The waiting is hard. Very hard. Try to keep busy and occupied. Biggest piece of advise, dont go doing too much research out on the internet. You will feed those dark thoughts you are having and it may very well be for no good reason.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 05:36AM marie5890 wrote: Chconnol, Hello and welcome to BCO. Having a biopsy done for calcifications is really quite common so don't panic (HARD NOT TO, though, we know this) Most biospies do come back B9 so hold onto that. (80%) If by some chance it does come back positive, take a deep breathe. From what you described it's in a very very early form. Breast cancer (and know that is an umbrella term that is used to describe a vast host of different kinds of cancer that can affect the breast) in the early stages is VERY treatable these days.   And "if" it comes back positive (and from what you said, I do emphasis "IF" ) it will take a bit more testing to find out exactly WHAT kind of cancer you are dealing with. And that will determine what kind of options and choices you have in dealing with it. My advice right now, hang tight as best you can while you  wait for the biopsy results.  Depending upon the results, then go from there. In the mean time, dont do too much research (it can be frightening if you dont know what you are dealing with).

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 12:53PM marie5890 wrote: Shachar, I can give you my experience with the radiologist coming in and doing more checking after the tech had done her part. She spent a great deal of time looking, taking messurements etc etc. Her look was serious and focus. In the end, something was there that only a biopsy could tell us what it was. It was a PASH tumor. Benign. When something is seen that isnt readily decernable as to what it is, it's not uncommon for the radiologist to come in and take a closer look. But that doesnt mean it's cancer. It just means that a biopsy is warrented. The truth is this in the end. Nothing is definitive for the most part until a biopsy is done. We have had women come in here with mammos and US that were "highly" suspicious for malignancy, but in the end, it was B9. We have also had women come here with mammos and US not really all that concern or suggestive of malignancy and have it come back as cancer. We have had everything in the middle to. It's really really hard to not to try and diagnose one's self with imaging alone. But only a biopsy is definitive. We are here for you either way. It is HARD we know.

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2012 03:19AM marie5890 wrote: Naw! You didnt sound agrumentative. It just struck me as odd about both the biop and the SNBiop...  You asked if it's possible for it to be so clearly cancer that even a tech can tell. The short answer is yes. Sometimes it is that obvious. They cant give you an official Dx though without a biopsy however. (There is a lady on this board who was told by her Dr that if for some reason the biopsy came back negative, that they would go in and do a lumpectomy to make sure they got the whole area because the Dr knew she had cancer. And she did.) If you were told there is a 95% chance of being cancer that means a BIRAD 5. We have had a couple of women this past year with a BIRAD 5 come back B9, but that it not the norm. Most of them do come back positive.   Other women on this board have had similar situations of being told that yea, that they had cancer and that the biopsy would confirm that. Sounds like you are absolutely surrounded by quality care for this.  That is good.  Take it one step at a time. And wait until you get all the information together. "Breast cancer" is really an umbrella term that describes all kinds of cancer that can effect the breast. What you may have may not be exactly what your sister has.  We are hear for you. There are also wonderful women in the other part of these boards who are on this journey. Though I think you are the first lady I know who may very well have it while dealing with your sister's treatment. That leaves me kind of dumbfounded on what to say to you.

A radial scar is amongst them. So there is a chance it can be B9. Just dont be taken off guard if it is cancer.In the mean time, dont do too much research on Dr Google. You dont have enough information. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a wide variety of different cancers that can effect the breast. If it is cancer, it will take a while before you get all the pieces of the puzzle together as to what specifically you mother is dealing with.  If you feel a need to get "some" information to start understanding the medical-eze, I recommend going to the homepage of breastcancer.org and click on the link of "diagnosis and treatment" There you will learn terms like "grade" "stage" "hormone receptors". It's a good place to start if this is your mother's journey.

Posts.Content: Dec 7, 2012 12:42PM marie5890 wrote: Yes, a BIRADS 4a is low risk for BC, so try not to panic. At this point you have no reason to. I will say this because women get confused over what constitutes risk for BC.  Most women who get BC are mothers, grandmothers, breast fed their kids etc etc, and have no family history, have lived very healthy lives etc etc etc The two BIGGEST risks for getting BC, and they are  THE doozies, are these. 1)Being female  2)Getting older.  The other risk factors are much smaller in comparison. Always keep that in mind. That is why it's important to get annual mammograms and follow up accordingly.  Dont get lulled into thinking you are "safe" because you can check off various "risk factors" with "no"  If you are a woman, and you are getting older, you are at risk. That is the reality. Keep up with your health

Posts.Content: Dec 18, 2010 02:22AM marie5890 wrote: First of all..HUGS...Waiting is excurciating especially when we are worried and fearful. "Focal asymmetry" is a way of describing what they see but cant, from the pictures taken, be called a mass yet. It means that more testing needs to be done to identify exactly what is going on. Is there a mass? They dont know. Is there not a mass? They dont know. etc etc  When more testing is done, then they can determine if its B9 or malignant. Ive been thru diagnostic mammograms (not the same as the normal screening mammogram, its more focused) and ultrasounds and just had an MRI done. My MRI showed that the focal asymmetry that was seen  "something new" from my past mammograms but not particularly suspicious. The reason I am being sent to a breast surgeon is because this is a new finding, although at this point it isnt all that alarming. But it does need to be checked out because it is "new" I know how your anxiety level has to be thru the roof. Try not to panic yet (I KNOW THAT IS HARD), but they simply dont have enough information yet on what they see to really say much of anything, only that they see a focal asymmetry.

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2012 11:09AM marie5890 wrote: Can a radiologist (who is an MD)  tell if it is cancer by looking at mammo or US? Im some cases yes. Those mammos and USs that are very highly suggestive of cancer are given a BIRAD 5....and in 95% of those cases, the biospy comes back conclusive that yes, it is cancer. But that said, most times when a woman is sent for a biopsy, (80%) it's because the radiologist can't tell if it's cancer or not. Most of the time, it's not, but the doctors are erring on the side of caution.

While you are waiting to get the biopsy and have more factual information come in based on your situation, I wanted to point out to you in the "Just Diagnosed" section of the  boards there is a great sticky thread at the top that is for newbies to help start getting your ducks in a row. It has some great practical advice as you begin this. A couple of thoughts for you at this point. 1)it's gonna take a bit of time to figure out what specifically YOU are dealing with. 'Breast cancer" is an umbrella terms that covers a whole host of different kinds of cancerS that can effect the breast. 2) If you find that anxiety, fear and worry are unmanagable, ask for a prescript for an anxiety med. Many women, including those who stear clear of pills, find that this is needed, esp in the early stages. There will be a great deal of information heading your and you need to be as calm as you can be as you navigate all of this. 3)Stay away from research a great deal at this point. Wait until you get more information. You will be hearing terms like "stage" "grade" "hormonal receptors" etc etc. The main page of breastcancer.org at the top has tab that is very helpful when it comes to understanding diagnosis, treatment, terms etc etc. Keep taking slow deep breathes. The beginning part of all of this is overwhelming. But hang in there. It will get better as things become clearer and a treatment plan is put into place

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2013 05:47PM - edited Dec 30, 2013 05:49PM by marie5890 Naturegirl, Yes stay off Dr Google. You have some great questions. One thing you can ask about since you have very dense breasts is having an MRI. In my state (CT) if a woman is most dense breast tissue, an MRI can not be denied them. So when you get the results of your biopsy, talk this over with the surgeon or the Dr. The different imagine shows different things. Mammos aren't that great dense tissue. US can't pick up microcals, MRI's pick up EVERYTHING and are notorious for false positives (and are expensive), so aren't ordered nearly as much. But if you have Extremely dense breasts, then I highly recommend talking to your Dr about getting one, if for no other reason to have a baseline of what your breasts are like.  The waiting is hard. I found the anxiety almost debilitating  Oh and the 50 years of age thing, push back against that. HARD. Don't accept that. There certainly are enough women here in there 40's with BC. Be proactive---even aggressive---with that one...

Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2016 07:57PM - edited Jan 15, 2016 08:00PM by marie5890 Shannon, definitely get a second opinion from an expert in the field. Just because you have a cousin who is a Dr in your family, doesn't mean they are an expert in this very specialized field. Also, find out what *grade* your DCIS is and what *form*..... Get solid information before making any drastic decisions like Mx or hysterectomy. And yes, second, even 3rd opinions. You are not in a situation that you have to make a decision *RIGHT NOW*. You have time to research and weigh your options based on YOUR individual situation. For example, with DCIS, you will not get chemo. It simply not done for DCIS. You are just in the very early stages. Get copies of all reports. Mammo and any other tests. Pathology of biopsy etc. ALL COPIES of everything, and start a folder.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2018 10:09AM marie5890 wrote: RA, I am so very sorry. Truly. Deep sigh You are going to have a great deal of information coming your way. I want to give you something to talk about with your team, especially your medical oncologist (the one who will be dealign with you when it comes to chemo Ask them about this Testing to determine which chemo works for your kind of cancer It's my understanding that this is newer technology. It tests a tumor with different kinds of chemo to see which works the best. The reason I say this is because I had a friend who was given 3 different kinds of chemo. When she had this test done about a year or so later, it showed that of the 3, only 1 was actually working for her kind of cancer. And it showed that another kind of chemo, typically used in colon cancer, would work for her. I know you are probably in a fog right now and that your memory may not be able to hand on to this, so print it out and mark with a marker on top of it "DISCUSS WITH MEDICAL ONCOLOGIST" I wish I could hug you.

Be a "joy" (for lack of a better term) to work with and not someone who has a reputation of being a pain. Trust me, you will stand out as someone they want to be helpful to and assist as oppose to someone that makes them cringe. You will get better care and better results

Posts.Content: May 22, 2011 06:32PM marie5890 wrote: Hello Linda and welcome. I too am sorry you find yourself in this situation. It is very scary. The answer to your question is, the are things that can be seen on imaging that are "red flags". Only a biopsy is definitive however. If your results come back positive, know you have found a great site to help you thru this. Where you are right now tends to be the more scary part of the journey. A couple of thoughts for you right now. BREATH slowly in and out. Seriously. It can help when the anxiety goes thru the roof. If the results are positive, try not to panic (HARD AS HELL THAT ONE) but try. There is a spectrum of different kinds of "breast cancer". It will take time and more testing to find out "what kind" you may be dealing with. If you need some help with staying "calm", make sure you ask your doctor for some help, prescription wise. Get copy of all your reports. There is a great thread in the "Just Diagnosed" forum that gives you tips how to get prepared. BIGGEST TIP: Doing research is good BUT it's important not to get too far ahead of yourself. That will only fuel fear and anxiety. And you dont need that. If you surf these boards try and stay within the threads that most match where you are at right now. Otherwise you will feel overwhelmed, never mind freaked out. Again you dont need that. In many ways, dealing with BC is "do-able". That is not to say it's easy, or like walking on the beach. But "do-able" Another big tip. If your results are positive, seek a breast surgeon, and if there is a "breast care" kinda of center in your area. You want a team of drs who know breasts. That its there main focus. Let the ladies here know what you need, how you feel. The sisterhood rages strong. :)

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2012 02:09PM marie5890 wrote: (Cut and pasting more info for you. Noting for you as well that angiosarcomas are very rare. 0.04% of ALL breast cancers. Meaning extremely rare) Pseudoangiomatous stromal hyperplasia (PASH) is a type of benign breast lesion that occurs as a single palpable mass or a dense region on a mammogram The masses observed in individuals with PASH are benign (non-cancerous) and require diagnosis only to distinguish them from cancerous (malignant) lesions.  It may be mistaken for angiosarcoma; however, the breast lesions caused by angiosarcoma are different than those seen in PASH The size of PASH lesions range from incidental microscopic findings to breast masses that are palpable or evident on a mammogram. Masses are usually large (5-6 cm in diameter), with reported diameters ranging from 1 to 12 cm.  The masses may grow over time PASH most commonly affects premenopausal women. The age range of people diagnosed with PASH is 14-67 years; however, most individuals are diagnosed in their late thirties or forties Surgical removal of the PASH lesions has been performed in some individuals.  A wide margin around the mass may be removed to prevent recurrence. Although PASH lesions often grow over time and may recur, they are neither associated with malignancy (cancer) nor considered to be premalignant (pre-cancerous).[1]  According to the medical text, CONN's Current Therapy 2007, approximately 7 percent of people experience a recurrence of PASH.[2]

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 05:02PM marie5890 wrote: Lillibell, (((HUGS)))  You need some perspective here since you have never had a mammo before. An "area of concern" does not means cancer. What it means is that there is something there, and they dont know what it is. Most of the time (80%) those areas of concerns are benign. Since this is your first mammo, there are no previous mammos to compare this "area of concern" to. They are just wanting to just check into it. It doesnt mean they think you have cancer. Not by any means. They just see something that they can't identify without a biopsy. I know that can seem confusing to us laypeople, but to them they just want to find out definitively "what is it" Again, most of the time (80% remember that number) "what it is" is something OTHER than cancer. Enjoy your holiday as much as you can. For those of us who have been thru the "tailspin of terror" we get what you are going thru. And we also know, you many very well be being afraid over something that is nothing. Deep breaths. Keep that perspective.

Posts.Content: May 4, 2012 09:24PM marie5890 wrote: There would be a couple of questions that come to my mind. 1) is did the doctor do a breast exam on you? Breasts are natually lumpy for many women and what you are feeling could be just normal breast tissues (fibrocystic breasts. 2) ask thme how dense your breast tissue is. At your age you should be loosing some density now. That is why mammos work better in women 40 and older and not so much younger women. Tissue density. 3) ask them did the mammo pick up any breasts conditions. (I found out when I got my last report that I have a fibroandenoma that I was never told about. I cant feel it. But it's never been a concern and it's never changed so no biggie IMO). 4) Im not sure about Canadian law, but here in the USA we, as patients have a legal right to copies of all reports. It cant hurt for you to have a copy of the actual radiologist's findings. That way, in the future, you, too, can compare. 5)You may find out that the mammo does pick up the lumps and that they can tell what they are (ie fibro, cyst etc). So to you question, should you push to see what the lumps are. I would say, first find out what the mammo report says. Then, based on what it says, then make a decision. Get the report first. That is what I would do, then proceed.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 07:21PM - edited Aug 29, 2011 07:26PM by marie5890 Oh Amy, First of all HUGS!!! Second, God got you thru what you needed to when you asked. He will get you thru the biopsy too, just ask. AFA the rest. Since there is a higher concern for malignancy, Im gonna recommend, when you are ready, to go to the "Just Diagnosed" forum and a sticky thread at the top called "Just Diagnosed--Get prepared" In that thread you will find some very practical advice and suggestions to help you thru the early stages if this indeed is BC. With that in mind, dont do too much research just yet. It would be awhile even if you get your preliminary results before you get a really clear picture of what YOU are dealing with. There are a multitude of cancers that effect the breast, each with its own characteristics. What the course of treatment is often differs a great deal person to person. You may want to get some basic understanding by going to the tabs at the top of the BCO page called "Symptoms and Diangosis" as well as "Treatment and side effects" This will give you a decent overview of BC 101. Have you been in contact with your other doctors that deal with your other medical issues? If not, it may be prudent to give them a call and start putting heads together thinking and strategizing. Gonna need a good team of Dr's who will have good communication with each other.   If your kids are in school, it also may be wise to contact the school  at some point.  See what kind of support system they can get going with your kids. God Bless

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2017 12:50PM - edited Jan 29, 2017 12:53PM by marie5890 Ok so if he ordered a biopsy based on your U/S, you have at least a BIRAD4. Based on the little that was in your report ..ie ""There has been an interval increase of the asymmetric density of upper outer quadrant of right breast"....it isn't screaming cancer. (With the caveat that we don't know what the US report said )The radiologist can't identify exactly what this is, so a biopsy will be done. Can radiologist look at something and based on their education make a good educated guess that it's cancer? Yes, they can. You are not in that situation. So hang tight. Dont do any internet research since you don't know enough to filter the information you come across accurately. The biopsy will let you know exactly what the "There has been an interval increase of the asymmetric density of upper outer quadrant of right breast" is all about. Many things happen to our breast, and most of those many things, are NOT cancer. Hang in there! The waiting is brutal, we know. If you decide to get a copy of the U/S report, we can help you understand that as well. Up to you. How old are you? Do you know how dense your breast tissue is? Is this asymmetrical density something they have been watching do you know over the years?

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 09:48AM marie5890 wrote: NanaDeb, you said: You're another young one. I find it horrible that women are led to beleive BC is an  old lady type cancer. Why do they say you dont need a mamo until 40????? Younger are left on their own with a false sense of safety I think. I AGREE completely. While "statistically" it is "older women" who get BC, there are plenty enough of younger women who get it too, where NO woman  should have a false sense of security, IMO. Not that women should walk around in fear of getting BC, but we all should be well educated in breast health no matter our age. Another reason, too, is that, typically, younger women Dx-ed with BC tend to have a more aggressive form of it, all the more reason to catch it early. To be fair on the "age 40" thing, the truth in that arena is that the younger the breast tissue, the more dense it is so even a mammo for a younger woman is no promise of finding anything suspicious. This can be true for even an older woman with dense tissue. Mammos are not fool-proof. That being said, I am glad that I came up with the guidelines that suggested getting a baseline mammo at 35 (I did) and then annuals starting at 40 (I have). It was because of that history of mammos that was able to show, that when I went for my annual last Nov., that there was a very clear new finding that had never been there in all previous films. I think that should be stressed for women. Get a baseline in your 30's. I live in CT where now it is required by state law (pushed by our former Gov. who was Dx-ed with BC while in office)  that each woman's mammo report let her know how dense her breast tissue is. If it meets a certain standard, then their insurance companies can not deny her a Breast MRI, which is a better way of screening very dense breasts. I hope this kind of law goes into effect across the states

Posts.Content: Nov 14, 2012 02:12PM marie5890 wrote: VollyBallMom, HUGS to you.  You are in a tough place. Pretty much waiting for the biopsy to confirm what the Drs suspect. That you have cancer.  I would think your nerves are raw and frayed. Take slow deep breathes. When you see the Dr on Friday, ask for a prescrip for an anti-anxiety or what they think would be helpful to you, emotionally speaking. You will have a basic Dx of cancer, but a more indepth Dx of exactly what kind of cancer, its characteristics (which will determine treatment) will take a bit longer. Chemo first, called neo-adjuctive chemo (I think that is the wording) is when they give you chemo to shrink the turmor. And MRI (and perhaps other testing) will give them a bigger and better picture of what is going on.  Read the information they gave you. Bring someone with you to your appointment to either write down or record what Dr says. Going emotionally "numb" and not hearing or understand everything that is said to you is normal. A lot of information is going to be coming your way and having someone there will help you since you wont be able to absorb everything. Try to stay focused on where you are at in your journey. Not everything, not even in these forums, will pertain to you. I hightly recommend that you go to the main page of breastcancer.org and look under the "Diagnosis and Treatment" tabs. There is all kinds of medical-eze to wade thru and breastcancer.org's main section breaks it down into lanuage that laypeople can understand God Bless

Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2013 11:48AM - edited Aug 3, 2013 11:49AM by marie5890 1) We all get the anxiety that you are feeling right now. No need to apologize of feel strange about posting here. This is the right place. At this point, just try to keep busy until they figure out what it is they are wanting more pictures of. Feel free to get copies of the radiologist reports of your mammos, U/S and any other testing you may have. Since you have concerns, and listed some risk factors, perhaps start a file of all these reports. You may be fine now, but for future reference as well. Remember this two. The 2 BIGGEST risks for getting BC are these. 1) Being a woman 2) getting older. Those even trump family history, etc etc. (Most of the women on these boards have had children and breast fed them, so I dont really buy into the *risks* of not having kids or not breast feeding them as truly risk factors) For now, try to stay distracted. You are in the " *what is it* waiting room" and that can be unnerving. Dont get ahead of yourself, and dont do too much googling. Truth is a lot of what you read is most likely outdated. Plus "breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a very very WIDE varieties of different kinds of cancerS that can effect the breast... Take deep slow breaths if you feel a wave of anxiety hit you.... Oh and with your dense breast tissue, (you didnt mention your age) you may want to consider getting an MRI. mammos dont do well with dense tissue...

Posts.Content: May 2, 2012 05:37PM marie5890 wrote: Leelee, Since that lump in your armpit is gone, that really isnt a symptom. If it were, it would still be there. So you get let that concern go. Lumps in breast is really doesnt sound worriesome because breasts are lumpy. It's when A  new and distinctive lump shows up that it needs to be checked out.  Has your right breast normally fuller than the left? If you are right handed, it should be. Breasts are not symmetrical. One is always fuller. It's only if this is a new finding that it needs to be checked out. I've gone over all your posts and what I do get is that you havent been aware of what is normal for your breasts....I'm betting that now you have looked a paid a ateention you are noticing what ids normal for you. Nothing you have wriiten is what I would call "symptoms of breast cancer". I would call it normal breasts for a 44 y/o woman.  Since you have never had a baseline mammogram before, it's good you went and had one. It will give them a baseline, plus it will give them a chance to see if anything needs a closer look. When new women come here I often use the analogy of what kind of flags are being raised---a red flag for serious cocern---a yellow flag for a semi-concern. From what you have wriiten, I wouldnt even say that you have raised a flag, red or yellow. Let's now wait and see what your mammo shows. Thus far, there is nothing you haven written is saying "breast cancer concern"...Nothing.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 12:46AM - edited Mar 14, 2016 12:49AM by marie5890 Sherri, since the report says BIRADS 4a, the report you have is not the pathology report of the biopsy itself, but rather the report of the U/S guided part of the biopsy. Which makes more sense. You will be getting another report, the actual report of the biopsy which will give you the answer as to whether or not it's cancer. Based on what the U/S report says in describing what was seen on the U/S, and the 4a, it's really leaning towards, and in a big way, being B9. IE not cancer. In more clear terms, you do not have the report from the core biopsy yet. What you have is the report of the ultrasound, since you had an ultrasound guided biopsy. The report from the biopsy is called a pathology report. Not a radiological report. :)

Posts.Title: Birad4 explanation pprice3122 marie5890

Posts.Content: Dec 31, 2011 03:11AM marie5890 wrote: What it basically means is that there is something there, and based on the radiologist's experience and training (they are doctors with a specialty), they see something that they can not say definitively "This is not cancer". SOO, the recommend a biopsy to find out exactly what it is. As you can see 3%-94% is a HUGE variable. More often than not, a biopsy done on a BIRAD 4 comes back B9.  On occation it does come back positive for cancer or precancerous conditions like ADH. The radiologist is saying "something is here, and I can not definitively say it's not cancer. It doesnt look like cancer, but I can say that it's not either". SO they recommend a biopsy be done to be sure.

Posts.Title: Results Sherri-lynn02 marie5890

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 01:22AM marie5890 wrote: A hypoechoic mass is a lump which appears relatively darker on an ultrasound scan, because it reflects fewer ultrasound waves. Punctuate means characterized by dots or points Echogenicity is the ability to bounce an echo, e.g. return the signal in ultrasound examinations. In other words, Echogenicity is higher when the surface bouncing the sound echo reflects increased sound waves. "punctate echogenicities and hypo echoic masses" is the medical-eze words used by the radiologist to describe how the ultrasound waves are reacting, and the image they are producing. So you have two masses showing up. Based on your entire radiological report, which includes the BIRADS 4a reading, it's not alarming. A BIRAD 4a is very close to a BIRAD 3, which means "probably benign" You have a good report there, with those two masses. :)

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2014 09:09PM marie5890 wrote: MinaBee, I am sorry that it is cancer.  With that, just a few practical things that will help in these early stages. BCO.org and it's main pages are a good beginning resource to get used to the medical terms (i.e. "grade" "stage" "hormonal receptors" etc. As with all cancers, "breast cancer" is an umbrella term used to cover a whole host of different kinds of cancers that can effect the breast. It will take a bit of time for YOUR picture to come into view. It will be based on that picture that a treatment plan will come together. Many times you do have options within that, based on what is found. If you need some sort of help with the dealing of the anxiety etc (anti-anxiety meds) please ask for them. Most women, including those who tend to push pills away do find that, especially in the early stages, the meds very helpful at keeping their head calmer. So don't hesitate if you think it would be helpful Top of this forum "Just Diagnosed" you will find a sticky for "newbies" Some very practical advice and insights that can help you get a sense of having control.  Most of the women who come here explain the process of "it's sucks, yea, but it was more do-able than I first thought" So, keep taking deep breathes.  Also know that on the weekends often times the boards get a bit more quiet as many of the women here "take the weekend off from anything cancer". Something to think about if you can. Though that may be hard for you since you just found out. You are not alone. Hugs...

Posts.Content: May 23, 2016 01:45AM - edited May 23, 2016 01:46AM by marie5890 Hi Jess and welcome. Your stress and anxiety is so very understandable, especially since you mother had BC. Tell that to your Dr so that they hear why you are scared. With that, this is something that is very important to understand. MANY things can happen to our breasts that have nothing to do with cancer. There a different kinds of lumps that are quite common in young women your age. Things like cysts, and fibroendanomas, etc. Infact, most lumps are NOT cancer. You are doing the right thing in getting that checked out. Any lumps or breast changes need to be checked out. It's not likely that they will recommend a mammogram for you because they don't work well with dense breast tissue, which at your age, you have. They may an ultra sound however which will work better. Now, based on your use of the word "Mum" and not "Mom", Im guessing you are either from Europe or Australia. I don't know what kind of laws or health care is at your disposal, but if you are extremely anxious over this, try to impress upon them that you need AN ANSWER definitavely one way or the other, which would mean a biopsy to put your mind at ease if an ultrasound does not give you a definitive idea of what is going on. (Here in the USA, we have a right to having copies of any reports, be it radiology or pathology etc. If that is something you, too, can get a copy of, if they do a U/S, get one. We can help.) In the mean time, get into the Dr and have it checked. STRESS to them that with you mother's BC at early 40's that you are very scared and anxious. That you need to know what this lump is about. Hang in there. We are here for you.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2011 01:20AM marie5890 wrote: Hi Mom2MissBee, On my radiologists reporsts (mammos, diagnostic mammos, ultrasound, and MRI) a focal asymmetry is seen. It means that there is an area that is seen that isnt seen in your other breast that has more. More often then not they arent anything to worry about. But with the family history of BC, it is important for them to find out exactly what the focal asymmtery is. (I go for a biopsy next week myself) BIRADS 0 means that there simple isnt enough information yet to say anything one way or the other. Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 09:33AM marie5890 wrote: rlwh, Hello and welcome to BCO. So sorry to hear you are facing a probably cancer dx.. (HHUGS) First of all, I agree with bgirl. Stay away from Dr Google. Until you know what exactly YOU are dealing with, he wont be helpful. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term that describes a whole host of different kinds of cancers that can affect the breast. Some are very aggressive and faster growing. Others are slow and sluggish. There are just too many variables because there are so many different kinds of cancers. Second. I am sorry for the lost of  your sister to ovarian cancer. My sister faced a possible ovarian cancer scare just 2 months ago. Things turn out B9, gratefully. But it was scary scary scary. Also important to point out, and I am no minimzing what your family experience with your sister. "Cancer" is very very scary. But not cancers are equal. As a general statement, ovarian cancer is far harder to deal with than many breast cancers. So keep taking those deep breaths that Jane suggested. You need to know what YOU are dealing with, you the the details. What you may be dealing with will be different from what you sister dealth with. And I say that, knowing that cancer, any cancer dx, is terrifying. Try hold onto facts when you get them. Hopefully it will help with the emotions, at least a bit. Also, if you do end up with a Dx of breast cancer, dont be afraid ask for a prescription of some sort of anxiety meds to help you thru. This wont be a time to "tough it out". Most women I have seen, even those who have said that they were stalwarts of strength, end up asking and needing something to help keep their mental health at an even keel. That is ok. You may want to head to the "Just Diagnosed" forum and start chatting with the ladies there for some insight and support if this does turn out to be BC. Ladies here are very supportive with holding each others hands and letting each other express fear, anger, anxiety, you name it God Bless and keep breathing
Posts.Title: Awaiting biopsy to diagnose cancer; worried and sad rlwh rlwh

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 09:57AM marie5890 wrote: BRCA 1 or BRCA 2 genetic testing. Since your sister did have ovarian cancer and you are looking at a probably BC cancer Dx, I think its a good idea, espically if you or your sister have children. If you want more information on this I would suggest the "women at high risk" forum. With the new health care laws I dont think insurance can drop you. Sounds illegal to me. For one thing, even women who do test positive for BRCA 1 or 2 it doesnt mean that they definitely will end up with cancer. It does mean that they are at a greater risk. Being a woman and getting older is actually more of a risk of getting BC than being BRCA 1 or 2 positive. But they do increase the risk

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2017 05:51AM marie5890 wrote: Hi Concerned, I've been reading thru your previous posts, trying to understand what you are dealing with. What I have come to understand is that you have had a biopsy done and your were diagnosed with a radial scar. A beign condition as you have come to read. Radial scars are always removed even though they are B9. Anything that is removed is also biopsied, which is normal protocol. Can cancer cell still be found? Yes, but HIGHLY unlikely. In all the years I have been here, I have known a handful of women Dx-ed with radial scars. None (with now the exception of Runor) have come back with a diagnosis of cancer after the radial scar was removed. I would recommend you stay off Dr Google as it seems that it's only confusing and down right scaring you.

Posts.Title: Mammogram this Thursday! So scared! Mom77 Mom77

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2016 09:20AM marie5890 wrote: HI Mom, There is a few things that can happen tomorrow. With the mammo, depending on what is seen, they may also do some diagnostic mammos (it's more focused imaging), possibly a U/S. The radiologist will make that kind of call. You may or may not find out tomorrow what the radiologist recommends. If the radiologist is there on site, you may be told right away either 1) they want a biospy, or2) a follow up mammo in 3 to 6 months, or 3) things are ok, nothing concerning. If the radiologist isn't there at the time, you it may take a day or so. You can ( and I would recommend this) request a copy of the radiologist's report, regardless. That way, you have something to refer to in the future if need me. For me, when I go to have mine done and I am signing in, I tell the receptionist that I want a copy of the report So will you find out anything tomorrow? The answer is it really depends. Maybe yes, maybe no. Don't expect the technician to tell you anything. If anything, they shouldn't. They are only there to take the imagining. They are not to give you any info as they are not the radiologist (who is an MD BTW). If they want a biopsy, again, don't freak out. Even 80% of biopsies are B9. Many times a biopsy is recommended as a matter of prudence, and not necessarily that they think you have cancer. It just that there are some thing that they can't say definitively that it isn't cancer and only a biopsy can do that.

Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2012 08:01AM marie5890 wrote: Purplecat Completely understand. And understand the anxiety. The reality is this. Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2017 08:47PM - edited Dec 6, 2017 08:48PM by marie5890 HI Apple Girl. To be honest, I don't think you really need to know the stage if the treatment place is just removal. You will get more information about the tumor itself (i.e. grade, type etc) from the biopsy which will happen from the surgery. That information is ultimately more important than stage. I think your mother has made a wise choice. If you go to the main page of BCO, you can get more information as to things like grade, type of cancer etc. You say you want to do the best thing for your mother? Does that mean she really isn't capable of making her own health decisions anymore (i.e. you are her PoA?). If she is capable of making her own decisions still, then it sounds like she is making the best thing for herself, which is a good. God's blessings!! And enjoy your time with your mother!!! Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2016 05:33PM - edited Jun 26, 2016 05:35PM by marie5890 Jersey Girl, once you find out what is the cause of your breast symptoms, it may be wise to discuss with your doctor of having some genetic testing done. How old was your grandmother when she had BC? And was it your maternal grandmother (your mother's mother?) Most times we have women coming here thinking that they have Paget's or IBC because of what they see, and it turns out to be a dermatilogical in nature (skin) issue....a fungal infection or something similar What you are describing is not BC symptoms so much as skin issues that just happen to be on your breasts. That's the difference. Good thing to have it checked out

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2016 06:14PM marie5890 wrote: No real tricks in figuring this out. Since this is the first imaging you have had done, they have noting to compare it to. With you being 30, it makes the mammogram you had not as effective (mammos don't do well with dense tissue, which younger women like yourself have). I wouldn't assume that you are looking at a diagnosis. If anything, it probably is B9. Even with your mother's BC, that doesn't mean you have an increased risk. That happens if there is a genetic componant to BC. Only genetic testing can determine that. Talk with the surgeon. A biopsy may be prudent, that is why they gave it a BIRAD 4. Or you may very well with being ok waiting 3 or 6 months follow up. What we are taught is that many things can happen to our breasts, most of which are B9. That included B9 lumps, like fiberandenomas, which are very common for someone your age. If it were me, I would go with the core biopsy, just for peace of mind.

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2016 08:18PM - edited Sep 14, 2016 08:19PM by marie5890 Hi Ashell. Im sorry to hear that it looks like you are most likely looking at a cancer Dx. You are in the toughest part right now, the waiting for information. To your question of "does a solitary lesion mean" that it seems to not have spread. The best answer is "perhaps". Did the Dr say how big the lesion was? First of all "breast cancer" is an umbrella term. There are over 20+ different kinds of cancer**S** that can effect the breast, not to mention subtypes. There are even subtypes to subtypes. There are many factors that go into the question of "has it spread". One of those things is called "grade". There are 3 grades. 1,2,3. Grade 1 is low grade, which means it's not as aggressive as Grade 2 o4 3, and less likely of spreading. That does **NOT ** mean that Grade 3 has definitely spread. It's just that Grade 3 is more aggressive and could possibly have. With that, it doesn't mean that Grade 1 does not spread. It can, too. Only more testing will give you the answer of "has it spread". There is so much to learn about BC and you are at the very beginning stages. So hang in there. Only testing is going to give you an idea of what *YOU* personally are dealing with. Stay off Dr Google. He will be of no help to you. Go to BCO's main site and there you can read the beginning ABC's of breast cancer and start getting used to the jargon. Keep breathing. Seriously, take some time to really focus on breathing

Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2011 09:13AM marie5890 wrote: RockyM (((HHHUGGSSSS)))))) I can see why you are so scared, and with good reason. You have found a great place. You are in the hardest part in so many ways. The waiting. Just a few things to help you thru at this point. 1)Breathe. Seriously. Especially when you feel all emotionally overwhelmed. Focus on take a few deep breathe. 2)Doing research is fine and being informed is important BUT, be careful. "Breast cancer" isn't "a" disease. It's a vast variety of different types of cancers. If yours does come back positive it's gonna take some time to find out exactly what you are dealing with. Try to stay in those threads that most closely resembles where you are at. Otherwise you are just going to get all the more anxious and overwhelmed. 3)there is a great thread in the "Just Diagnosed" forum called "Just Diagnosed:Get prepared" there is some excellent, practical advice there on what you can do as you head down this path, if you do, indeed head down this path 4)Dont panic (I know I can hear ya, "Yea right, dont panic. HA!"  )  Seriously, though, dont feel you have to do everything "right now". You do have sometime to gather information, get second opinions, as far as treatment. There is a great tab at the top of the page called "Treatment and side effects". 5)If things really do get so overwhelming and you get so anxious that it becomes difficult to function, talk to your Dr about getting a prescription for something to help with the anxiety. It's not uncommon for someone in the beginning to "get a little help" in the beginning as you get used to the new information. In the mean time, feel free to vent here, ask questions, whatever you need.

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2013 04:45PM marie5890 wrote: Hello Hbranden and welcome. I understand your anxiousness, we all do. Unfortunately, can't really give you the kind of data you are asking for. They dont really exsist, "chances of such and such a symptom=breast cancer" Why is that? Because soo many things can happen to our breasts that have nothing to do with breast cancer. You are however doing the right thing by having it checked out.  It's not likely the breast surgeon will do a biopsy right then and there unless it is a cyst and she asperaties it. At least that is my understanding. Will she request an MRI? Possible, but it's not normal protocol to have an MRI prior to a biopsy unless it is known that a woman has very dense breasts. Insurance companies arent too fond of MRIs do to their expense and high false negative results. You are right, however, most women, 80%, who go on for a biopsy end up with B9 results. From what you posted  about your mammo and U/S, nothing is screaming "cancer" (and yes, there are things that can be seen on imaging that can look highly suspicious for cancer. Yours does not by what you posted) It's hard, the not knowing, but try not to panic. What you are describing can be explained by other conditions other than breast cancer. Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Dec 23, 2011 08:23AM marie5890 wrote: Ask if its something along the lines of "Atypical Ductual Hyperplasia" (ADH) or "Atypical Lobural Hyerplasia" (ALH). These can be pre-cursers to cancer (or some experts think the stage before cells actually turn into cancer, though there is not complete agreement on this) If so, you would be considered at "high risk" and if so, some places actually have programs for women at high risk. Also ask if you are indeed at higher risk, what kind of pro-active monitoring screening is going to be recommended (many women with ADH or ALH having screenings 2X a year rather than just yearly; also some alternate been mammo,US and MRI etc since each screening technique shows difffernt things. Here is a link to help you understand "Atypical" breast cells http://www.dslrf.org/breastcancer/content.asp?L2=3&L3=2&L4=1&SID=162

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2016 04:14PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Beth and welcome. I am so sorry about the loss of your sister. Grief is overwhelming and the trauma magnifies it all. First off, stay away from Google. You don't 1) know enough and 2) have enough information to do a research with the right kind of ability to filter thru the nonsense and even outdated material. You did the right thing with having a doctor check out the lump. Know this, however, most lumps are B9. Because of all the "pink washing" with the awareness campaigns over the years, we tend not to think in terms of a lump being B9. We tend to think of cancer. And that is backwards thinking in the light of reality. Many things happen to our breasts and most of them have nothing to do with cancer. For example, you mentioned a young child, so I am guessing you are either in your 20's or 30's. Most lumps for women of this age are things like cysts, or something called fibroendenomas, and they are common, and they are B9. Like I said, you ARE doing the right thing in having it checked out. So don't feel like you are overreacting with having it checked. Just know, that the odds are heavily, yes heavily, in your favor that it's B9. Hang in there. And STAY AWAY FROM GOOGLE ;) HUGS

Many things will show up on those tests that they will ask to have a biopsy for to be on the safe side. Know that 80% of all BIOPSIES come back B9 (ie non-cancerous) There are things that can show up on a mammogram or ultra-sound that can either look like a "yellow flag" or a "red flag". If you have copies of your reports some of us here can help you understand why you had a biopsy. For now, dont panic. "breast cancer" is an umbrella term used to call a whole host of differnt cancers that can effect the breast.

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2017 12:53AM marie5890 wrote: Link to help you understand what the phrase architectural distortion means. It's not a diagnosis. It's a phrase used by radiologist to describe what is seen on a mammogram. You don't "get" architectural distortion. It's like saying a piece of cloth has a wrinkle. So the question is, why does the cloth have a wrinkle. Your diagnosis was a radial scar. That is what caused the distortion on the mammogram image. The normal protocol is to have a radial scar removed. Concerned, I'm going to be very blunt here, while at the same time respecting the frustration you are experiencing. Perhaps you are experiencing anxiety as well. Everyone here knows what a trip anxiety is. You have been given the blessing of having a B9 finding. Yes, there is a small chance of malignant cells that can l be found, and that is why it's protocol to remove a radial scar. To make sure there are none. The women here are fighting for their lives. In fact, in the Stage IV forum, those women are fighting for time. You are not. Please keep that in perspective. Given that perspective, I find your post comes off as being insensitive to what the women here are going thru. You are very fortunate. The women here who are fight for their lives, or more time, would have given their eye teeth to have been given the diagnosis of a radial scar. Count your blessings rather that focusing on the hiccups that you have been experiencing in the diagnostic process. You still come out with "YAY!!! B9 finding!""

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2012 11:31AM marie5890 wrote: Hello Luke22--- Yes that happened to me. I went for a US guided biopsy after a "new finding" was found on my annual mammo and subsequent US done at the time. When I went for the US guided biopsy, they couldnt find the area, so they did more diagnosic mammos again. It showed up in some of the images but not all. The radiologist was perplexed so advised an MRI to make sure that it just wasnt some fold of skin or something before trying again with another biopsy. MRI did pick it up. So then I went for a steretactic biopsy. It came back as PASH. Its rare and when it is found, it tend to be just an incidental finding. Mine was an actual lesion. Good luck! Let us know what the results are.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 07:54AM marie5890 wrote: Lucky, One of the  advantage of MRI's when it come looking for BC is that it is checking for blood flow (its why you are given the contrast dye) , they are watching to see what and how quickly that contrast dye is picked up by anything and how quickly it disappates. (the word "enhancement" is often used From what you posted,  there was no suspicious enhancement of areas going on.  I have no clue as to what is going with your breast, but really, according to the MRI results, there is nothing alarming going on when it comes to the blood flow (cancer needs a blood supply to grow), there is no concerning enhancement. Keep looking to get an answer. After my MRI, it was clear that something WAS there, but because there was no alarming enhancement, I was pretty confident that it wasn't cancer. But I kept going until I found out what is was, because something WAS there that as new. For me, it turned out to be a PASH tumor (its a benign rare kind of tumor)  (Its that alaraming enhancement that also makes MRI give a lot of false positives. Many things can cause it, not just cancer. MRI's are notorious for false positives)  Reading what you posted, you really do have good reason to exhale. Biopsy is prudent for sure, but you really do have reason to exhale.

Posts.Content: Jun 18, 2012 12:34PM - edited Jun 18, 2012 12:37PM by marie5890 There are all kinds of things that can make cells enhance on an MRI. It's why they are notorious for false positives. And it's just not the enhancement that is being looked at on an MRI. The speed of "washing out" as well. (IE how quickly the enhancement disapates) "Heterogeneously enhancing cells" in and of itself is not all that alarming. Having it biopsied is the wisest course of action. Here is a link that may give a bit more of insight into MRIs and enhancment breast-cancer.ca/screening/mri...  Good luck to your sister.
