Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2011 10:35AM marie5890 wrote: Trust me, I understand the deep fear and anxiety.  I know how the internet searching can just add fuel to that fire and make it a raging inferno of profound terror.  I went and read your posts. It's my understanding that monthy BSE haven't been part of your routine for the most part, right? So, keeping that in mind, you are not used to what your breast normally feel like. What you are feeling may very well be part of your normal breast structure. Breast are more than just fat; they have all kinds of tissues and structures to them. That's one of the reason young women are encourage to do BSE so that they can get to know what their normal breasts feel like, so that when something does show up, they will sense that it's new and different.  Considering your experience with your mother, I can well understand your shying away from BSE. Let's look at what you know at this point. Your risks factor at this point is that your mother had it. That is a legit risk factor. That doesn't mean you *WILL* get BC, but it does increase your risk. That being said, most women who get BC don't have family history.  It is very rare for someone in your age bracket to get BC. As you know, not impossible, but indeed rare.   I think what is happening to you (and it's very understandable. It happened to me) is that your fear, your terror is fueling your imagination. And now your imagination is F-ing with your head and your heart. Very understandable. My advice? Keep reminding yourself you have *NO FACTS* at this point when what you are feeling. You have deep fear, deep terror, but no facts. Keep holding onto that fact. Again, a person can not tell by how it feels. Not even doctors can do that, and they are trained. What you may be feeling for all we know is part of a duct, or a lobe, or a fibroendanoma, etc etc. Keep reminding yourself of that. Since you are just getting used to what the structure of your breast feel like, you really dont know if what you are feeling is completely normal for you. Hang in there. If I recall right you go for a US tomrrow. In the meantime, stop examing your breast. You seem to be inadvertantly just throwing another log on the bonfire of terror. And that is not helping your right now. Let us know how it goes. We are here for you.

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 01:21PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Paula and welcome. Itsjustme gave you a good run down. A BIRAD5 is not a diagnosis of cancer, but more of a rating system that radiologists (who are specialized  trained medical doctors) use to flag areas of concern. Most women who come thru here who have had a BIRAD 5 do end up with a positive diagnosis of cancer, but I have seen a few who turned out to have a B9 condition that mimics cancer on imaging (they tend to be either radial scars or fat necrosis). So, like itsjustme said, you wont know definitively until you get a biopsy done. The radiologist is just making a very educated guess based on his training and experience. Praying that it's something other than BC. God Bless

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2014 07:05AM - edited Apr 2, 2014 07:13AM by marie5890 I have struggled with anxiety the past couple of years. Not related to BC, but other medical conditions. One thing that has helped me is to identify when the anxiety flares and what am I doing at that moment that is possibly triggering the flare. It doesn't fix the anxiety, but at least I become more self-aware as to what some possible triggers are. And I have learned that, for me, researching on the internet the medical conditions or symptoms that are present is a BIG trigger. Google in so many ways is not my friend when it comes to putting myself at a website that may or may not having anything to do with what the reality is.  I find it a real balancing act of "being informed" and "scaring myself and making the anxiety FLARE" …..Im facing that right now with a loved on who is going in for treatment next week for a medical condition. Chances are she will be ok, but there is this fear that echoes in "Grand Canyon" of my mind…and it goes on and on and on and on….Forcing myself NOT to do anymore research at this point as the treatment MUST be done. It's the long term risks that are scaring me, though. I have been told (but not sure if it's true) is that since I am perimenopausal, that too can add to the anxiety.  It sucks, whatever the reasons.

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2011 08:28PM marie5890 wrote: I would go with the American College of Radiology BIRADS link since they (ACR) are the ones who devised it. http://www.acr.org/secondarymainmenucategories/quality_safety/biradsatlas/biradsfaqs.aspx BIRADS 4 is actually broken down into 4a, 4b, 4c. Many variables play into the ratings. Some of those variables include, but not limited to, age, family history, personal history, imaging findings etc. Radiology is not an exact sciene and it's prudent on all of us to do our own research as best we can, keeping in mind we are not trained in this field.

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2012 07:08PM - edited Apr 20, 2012 07:09PM by marie5890 Ronnie, Hello and Welcome. Best advice is to STAY AWAY FROM DR GOOGLE. Most of what you are reading has zero, zero, zero to do with what you are dealing with. Why do I say that? Because you dont know what you are dealing with. The truth is "breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a whole host of DIFFERENT kinds of cancers that can affect the breast. Kinds that only can be determined under a microscope. You dont have any pathological data on your lump so you have nothing to go on other than you have a lump. Dr GOOGLE doesnt have the data need to wade thru all the TONS of stuff that is out there and find what is right for YOU personally.  Most lumps found in women's breast are NOT cancer. Your BIRADS 4a means that even the radiologist is leaning more towards that it's not cancer more than they believe it is.  But they are being prudent and professional by having it biopsied so that they know for sure. Hang in there and STAY AWAY FROM DR GOOGLE. DR GOOGLE doest know what your lump is about....

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2011 07:57PM marie5890 wrote: Eileen, What kind of questions do you have? Perhaps we can help with some of them. AFA your question of how can someone feel good and still have breast cancer? Many women who end up with a  Dx-ed with  breast cancer feel fine. Many have lived very healthy lives infact. A person doesnt necessarily have to feel sick in order to have cancer. But it is a mind-twist, isnt it. The idea of it being possible of having cancer and yet feeling absolutely fine.  And with the advancement of technology and the ability to find many cancers in earlier stages adds to that. There are reasons why a BIRADS of 5 is given. Many cancers have a certain look to them. A well trained and experienced radiologist knows what these looks are. That is why they flag them BIRADS 5  Again it's not a given that it is cancer; like carpediem said, there have been other ladies here in these past months who were given a BIRADS 5 and it came back negative. SO there are other conditions that can mimick what  cancer can look like on a US or mammogram  and fool a radiologist.

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2011 06:24PM marie5890 wrote: Evening Eileen, Sure it always possible to have more than one mass in a breast.  Before I go on to answer your question, what kind of biospy did you have? There are several kinds Stereotactic (you lie on a special table where the breast hangs down thru a hole. Then mammography like  paddles compress the breast and they decide exactly how they are going to approach the mass) US guided biopsy (the ultrasound machine is used to to aide the radiologist/surgeon to the mass) etc. For me, I had a stereotactic biop and had a lot of brusing and most of the brusing (and there was a lot of it)  was due to the compression of the paddles. The actual site of where the needle went was much much less.  My mass was very close to the chest wall and surrounded by some fairly large viens so they didnt go for a direct route, but a route that would avoid the veins.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2012 04:44PM marie5890 wrote: Cla, I think you have a distorted understanding of what a biopsy is. They will be taking very small string like core samples of the area. They will then take these samples and put then under a microscope to look at it at the cellular level. Will the BS be able to tell you in a general sense if there is reason for high alarm. Yes he can, but it will only be a general educated GUESS.  Nothing factual and definitive. Only a biopsy can do that. Depending on where the samples are sent and what their normal time table is, it can be a couple of days to about a week for results to come back Googling really isnt very wise because you really dont know what exactly you need to be looking for in all honesty.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 05:49PM marie5890 wrote: There was definately a new finding on my annual mammo. Had a US done and it was seen then. Went to have a US guided biopsy but they couldnt find it that time. So more diagnostic mammos pictures were taken. It showed up in some views but not others. The radiologist thought, since the first attempt at a biopsy was a no-go, to go ahead and have an MRI to see if something was actually there to biopsy since it seemed to play "hide and seek"  The MRI showed something was definately there. The off to the BS. He wasnt sure exactly what it was, but he didnt think it was cancer. He did,however, think it was prudent to get a definite answer as to what it was... It turned out to be a PASH. And not just the incidental findings that can sometimes show up in cancer. It was it's own 9mm x15mm mass.  So, yes, MRI are more often done AFTER a Dx, but not always. There can be exceptions.

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 01:59AM marie5890 wrote: You are welcome.  It IS frightening to find a lump. We have had it drilled into our heads since very young teens about breast lumps and the need to have them checked out. And this is true. But sometimes the "rest of the story" does get lost in that understandable fear. 1) that most lumps are NOT cancer 2) that THE number one risk for breast cancer is ..being female...and the second biggest risk? Getting older. All those other risk factors (having children vs not, breast feeding vs not, life style etc) all are "factors" but not nearly as real risk factors as we may imagine. Exceptions to that being, 1) hormonal replacement therapy and if has the BRCA gene mutations (this is where family history  can suggest there is a gene mutation) Most of the women on this site who do or have fought BC are mothers. Many of nursed their children etc. Many of them, like you, have lived very healthy life styles. etc Again, all that said, most lumps, esp at  your age, are something other than cancer.

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2011 09:27AM marie5890 wrote: Calcifications come is two varities... Macro and Micro... It's the micro-calcs that *can* be a warning sign that cancer *may* be present, but never a guarentee. Calcs in and of themselves arent cancer. They *may* be the left overs of cancer cells dying off. Even with mirco-calcs it is not that they are present that is sometimes a flag; they are often there. Its *HOW* they appear, their pattern if you will...Are they forming a circle? are in a linear form? If so, then *may be* something is going on. That is when a biopsy is recommended when micro-calcs are present, if they are in those patterns that raise a flag of suspicion. From your post this is what I sense the doctor is saying to you. 'There are calcs present. We are going to compare them to your last mammo and if they are changing their pattern and doing something that may raise a concern, we will let you know. To look at then right now, there they are not alarming" Hope that helps

Posts.Content: Dec 20, 2011 09:43PM marie5890 wrote: The best precautions you can take is to keep doing what you are doing. Living a healthy life style, doing SBE's faithfully so you get to know what is "normal" for your breasts. That why, when something is unusual, you can get it checked out When you 35 years old, get a baseline mammogram. Then annual ones from 40 years on. Again, the biggest risks for getting breast cancer you already have. You are a female and you are gettting older. Because of that, you and the rest of us are always at risk.  I know that there is some concern when it comes to use of birth control pills. I think it's because they are hormones. Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 12:43PM marie5890 wrote: Hello Nancy, Sorry you find yourself in the "what is it" position. I've been in that boat for about a month now. Like you know, ultimately, only a biopsy can give the definitive answer. But if you are asking, are there things that can be seen on a mammo, ultrasound, or MRI that are warning signs, or yellow/red flags to the tech or radiologist, the answer is yes. Depending on their experience and training will also impact what they are seeing. Also, some are more aggressive in finding answers, others less so. Remember, they too are human beings. And how they react will also be impacted based on their own personalities. Again, warning signs can be seen on the various imaging tests, but only a biopsy can give you are definite answer. My personal thoughts to you is, dont get sucked up completely by their reactions (you used the word "grim") because you cant really tell what that means. At the same time, dont dismiss it outright either. They see something that makes as a professional, a flag go up for them.  So take a deep breath, write down all the questions you have. Do some research if you feel like it (I found the symptoms & diagnosis section of this site very helpful in that). As a new person to this board you will only be able to post 5 posts a day (protects the site from spam) until you get to 50, but you have unlimited "private messaging" capabilities. Feel free to use that if you need to. God Bless

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2016 10:17PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Bookworm and welcome. Don't panic. This is your first mammo and U/S and they are just taking a closer look at what was seen. This is what as known as your baseline imaging and as you go forward in the years to come, they will be comparing those images with previous images to see if there are any changes Truth is many things, even lumps and masses, happen to our breasts and most of them have nothing to do with breast cancer. Even when biopsies are recommended, it's not because they think it's cancer, as 80% of biopsies are benign (non-cancer) What you are reacting to is what many of us call "pink washing ", meaning we have heard since we were young teens, if you find a lump, check it out (which is true). But what they failed to tell us, is that it's most likely not cancer, but it's just wise to have it checked out.

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 08:58AM marie5890 wrote: It's a dated study, and it's full of medical-ease http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/16080490 Division of Cell and Molecular Biology, School of Animal and Microbial Sciences, The University of Reading, P.O. Box 228, Whiteknights, Reading, RG6 6AJ, UK. p.d.darbre@reading.ac.uk The upper outer quadrant (UOQ) of the breast is the most frequent site for incidence of breast cancer, but the reported disproportionate incidence in this quadrant appears to rise with year of publication. In order to determine whether this increasing incidence in the UOQ is an artifact of different study populations or is chronological, data have been analysed for annual quadrant incidence of female breast cancer recorded nationally in England and Wales between 1979 and 2000 and in Scotland between 1980 and 2001. In England and Wales, the recorded incidence of female breast cancer in the UOQ rose from 47.9% in 1979 to 53.3% in 2000, and has done so linearly over time with a correlation coefficient R of +0.71 +/- SD 0.01 (p < 0.001). Analysis of independent data from Scotland showed a similar trend in that recorded female breast cancer had also increased in the UOQ from 38.3% in 1980 to 54.7% in 2001, with a correlation coefficient R for the linear annual increase of +0.80 +/- SD 0.03 (p < 0.001). These results are inconsistent with current views that the high level of UOQ breast cancer is due solely to a greater amount of target epithelial tissue in that region. Identification of the reasons for such a disproportionate site-specific increase could provide clues as to causative factors in breast cancer.

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2016 09:06PM marie5890 wrote: It's a description of some microcalcification that are seen on your mammogram. Not sure if this is your first mammogram or if it's your annual. In and of themselves, microcals are B9. Sometimes, they are an indication of possible early stage cancer. If this is your annual, what is seen this time will be compared to what was on your previous mammos. A diagnositic mammo may be recommended, which is just a closer look at this specific area. It's also possible that a biopsy may be recommended to make sure things are ok. Is it overly concerning? No. But it is something that they may want to take a closer look at.

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 12:25AM - edited Feb 23, 2011 12:26AM by marie5890 Jade, No such thing as a silly question when you are delving into unfarmiliar territory  I had a stereotactic biop at the end of Jan. Be prepared to be there for a 1.5-2 hours...Not that it takes that the biop itself takes that long, but the setting up, getting in position, them giving you instructions will. A snug bra can be just one of your tighter fitting bras (they will give you a small ice pack, I mean really small) or a sports bra.... Be prepared to find a position laying on your belly for about 30 mins. Because once you are in position and they set up the equipment, you really cant move. You certainly will be able to work if you want I would think. What time is your appointment set up for? My only thoughts are though if you want to keep an ice pack on the site to help keep the swelling down. Do you have access to a freezer where you work? Is it "absolutely necessary" to ice it? I dont think for me it was, but it does keep the swelling down, and I dont think I would have swelled up all that much. Hopefully other women who have had a stereotactic will speak up with their experiences... I know for me, I would have been fine going to work after. It just so happens my appointment was set for 2 pm so by the time I was done (345) the work day was over

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2013 03:10PM marie5890 wrote: Grace, I have (or should say had) PASH.  Normal protocal is to have it removed, but it's not absolutely necessary unless it is 1)causing pain, 2) so big that it may be hiding other areas of concern or 3) keeps growing. I chose to not have mine removed, and it actually ended up going away on it own, which is something it is also known to do.  So you have options. You can get a 2nd opinion, you can wait and see if it grows and then decide, you can have it removed, etc.

At this point, they aren't sending you for a biopsy (which, even then, most of the time, that is precausionary) Honestly, try not to panic. And don't do any researching. Your imagination is going to dark places without having any hard core data. WE ALL GET THAT. Trust me. We all have been down that road. So, go and see the breast surgeon. Get copies of the radiologist report. One step at a time. Chances are, especially if the radiologist wasnt concerned right off the bat, that you are fine. They are just being prudent. Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2011 09:14PM - edited Dec 30, 2011 09:15PM by marie5890 Luce... MRI do pick up everything. But it's not just whether something "lights" up with the contrast dye. (Fancy way of saying they are looking at the blood flow to the area in question) With a BIRAD 4 dont be surprised if they recommend a biopsy. You will see that kind of recommend with that rating. Dont panic. Thus far, everything you have posted isnt alarming. It's more of a "what is it"

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2013 04:28PM marie5890 wrote: Hello NotReady and welcome... First of all (((HUGGGSSSS)))) I hear your fear. It is scary... To answer some of your questions since you are looking for answers. 1)Yes, we do have women here in their 30's (and even later 20's) who have been Dx-ed with BC. We will point you in their direction if it comes to that. They even have their own threads in various forums. 2)The things you have posted, "spiculated" is a flag for cancer, but only a biopsy will show for sure (other things can mimic that look and not be cancer. I have seen several women with that and have it not be cancer) 3)It "lit up on MRI contrast". That also can be a flag for cancer. But you need to know this about MRI's, they are notorious for false positive and many thing can "light up" on and MRI and not be cancer. Again, only a biopsy will know for sure. So, yes, you do have some "flags" that are leaning towards cancer, but only a biopsy can tell you for 100% sure. Whether or not a woman has chemo, regardless of age, depends on what kind of breast cancer it is and how far along it is. You see, "breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a whole host of differenct cancerS that can effect the breast. IF, and I stress IF, you do have cancer, it will take awhile for YOUR particular picture to come into view. There will be testing of the area for things like "hormonal receptors" (basically what hormones, if any, are causing your cancer to grow, how much and how fast) STAY AWAY FROM DR GOOGLE UNTIL YOU KNOW WHAT IS GOING ON. He will only frighten you and you dont have the medical background to sift thru what he has to say (and a lot of it may be outdated) How can we help you in the mean time?

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 02:54AM marie5890 wrote: Hi Lina and welcome. Pre-cancerous can mean ADH or ALH (? I think they are both considered precancerous ??) Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia or Atypical Lobular Hyperplasia If my understanding is correct "some" consider DCIS as pre-cancerous, but for the most part, it is considered cancer that is not invasive. When you get your results, ask for a copy of them. No doubt your head may be in a whirlwind and we can help you understand some of the language. Is it possible that it could still be B9? Yes that is possible. Based on what you were told, however, be a bit mentally prepared that it's not B9. Only a biopsy can really give you a definitive answer (there are some B9 conditions that do mimic cancer on imaging, so there is where the possibility lies) Based on the bit you have shared of what you were told, what the Dr saw has a look of either precancer or cancer, and the biopsy will tell you if that is correct. SO hang tight!! (ITS HARD we know) When you get your diagnosis and if you feel the need to ask for a prescription for an anti-anxiet medical (esp if it's cancer) don't be afraid to ask for it. Most of the women who get a diagnosis, and even those who really DONT like taking pills, admit that in the beginning stages of the journey, some form of anti-anxiety aid was indeed helpful. DONT DO ANY RESEARCHING on what you are told quite yet. IF you do have cancer, it's going to take a bit of time for ALL of the pieces of the puzzle to fall into place. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term that covers a whole bunch of different cancerS that can effect the breast. And each kind, and the staging of it, has different approaches.  The ladies here can help you with unraveling that information given to you, what it means, and how it will impact you going forward. BREATH…KEEP BREATHING…SLOWLY… *IF* it is cancer, the fact that it has the look of possibly being pre-cancer means to me you caught it early….THAT is good
Posts.Title: Biopsy results: benign vs pre-cancerous Lina999 awb

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2014 04:32AM marie5890 wrote: Renee, Hello and welcome Since you understand what BIRAD4 means, the "b" has to do with some clinics breaking down BIRAD4 even further with BIRAD4a 4b or 4c… 4b means you are right in the middle of the range of what percent of BIRAD4's are either diagnosed as either cancer or not. The "a" is more towards the lower end of the scale, the "c" the higher, and the "b" the middle. In my layman's way of explaining….BIRAD4c is closer to a BIRAD4   BIRAD4a closer to a BIRAD3 and BIRAD4b and right between the two. There is a suspicion of it being cancer, but it's not a red flag, it's a yellow flag…. Hope that helps

Posts.Content: Aug 19, 2011 07:54PM - edited Aug 19, 2011 07:57PM by marie5890 Mammograms have not been moved to 50. It was a recommendation but has been rejected. One of the reasons that it was recommended is because most women who get a call back for a diagnostic below the age of 50 turn out to be nothing and the women F.R.E.A.K. Out with the call back. IE there is a lot of undue stress and anxiety. Same recommendations still stand. Baseline at 35, annuals starting at 40.   I see it as poor education. Women are taught, and rightfully so, never to ignore a lump. To get it check. What women are NOT taught, is the most lumps arent cancer. So women are set up to freak out because they have been poorly educated over breast health. AFA your first question. The truth is MOST women Dx-ed with BC have NO family history. That is the factual reality. That idea of the "family history" tends to lull women into complacency if you ask me. They think "I have no family history so I am safe." Not true Biggest risk for having breast cancer is being a woman. Having family history increases the risk (though I think that is more true if there is BRCA1 or BRCA 2 positive gene going on). Here is a link to more information on Breast cancer risk www.cancer.org/Cancer/BreastCa...  My own advice to any woman who finds a lump. Get it checked but dont freak out.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 03:09PM - edited Jan 21, 2014 03:13PM by marie5890 Hi Petal and welcome. Both the intraductal papillomatoisis and the cysts are B9 conditions. They are not cancer. The intraductal papillomatoisis does increase your risk for future cancer a bit, but not much. The fact that you are a woman and as you age is still your biggest risk, as is true for all women And since you had an MRI, which with your breast density is a wise thing, they got a real good look at what was going on.  Have intraductal papillomatoisis removed is normal. Don't be afraid. There is nothing scary in your report…  Here is a link to help you understand *intraductal papillomatoisis* http://breastcancer.about.com/od/whenitsnotcancer/p/intrad_papill.htm So take some slow deep breaths. You are ok.  God bless

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 08:56PM marie5890 wrote: Hi Ashisonfire,  And welcome to the board we all wish wasn't necessary but grateful that it exists when we need it. I had my biopsy this afternoon. I had a stereotactic which is a tad bit different from and US guided but it's all for the same idea just different ways of imaging the area they want to biopsy. Mine really wasnt that bad at all. They do numb the area so really all you feel is pressure. The idea of it I found (IE imagination) to be worse than the actual biopsy. My sister went with me (and drove) to be my support system but I would have been fine if I had to drive myself. That said, if you find that you normally are freaked out over medical procedures you may want someone there. My appointment was at 2pm and I was done by 3:45 so it is a bit of a wait. Although I think US guided biopsies may require less time. One thing I would recommend. Wear a sports bra. The extra compression is not only supportive but also helps the healing process. Try not to worry (HARD WE ALL KNOW!) Most biopsies come back B9 (80%). It's just safer to actually find out what the lump is about rather than ignore it. Ask away if you have questions (as a newbie on the board you are limited to 5 posts a day ..keeps spammers at bay...but you can PM unlimited...Just click on the person's name and it will bring you to their profile page, from there you can PM) God Bless

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2011 06:21PM marie5890 wrote: Eileen, In general from what I have noticed various ladies go thru from getting a Dx to beyond is that it takes a little bit of time for one's personal situation to come into view. Like I have said before, the term "breast cancer" is an umbrella term the covers a wide variety of cancers that can effect the breast. It takes some time for all information to come in before a treatment plan to be put into place depending on exactly what is going on. Many women also seek second opinions on treatment plans. Esp those with early stage. There is a great thread in the "Just Diagnosed" section entitled "Just Diagnosed-Get prepared". In there many women find useful, practical advice on what they can do to "get their ducks in a row" as they proceed on this journey. Between a diagnosis and treatment actually getting under way, women take this time to educated themselves on what kind of situation they personally are deal with based on the results that come in. Also, many women often feel anxious and ask their Dr's for some sort of anti-anxiety to help them stay in a calmer place as they want to have as clear and as calm (as possible) of a head on their shoulder. If your results do come back positive, you may seriously consider asking for some sort of prescription like that. You may never need it, but it may be good to have, just in case.

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 08:19AM - edited Jan 11, 2013 08:20AM by marie5890 Hello Hoping and welcome. I took a bit of time to read up on your posts to understand where you are at. Nothing you have written is screaming cancer. Not by a long shot. It sounds like you have some good doctors who are being prudent, especially since your mother is a survivor (YAY for her!!) and just wanting to know what the microcals are about. More often than not, they mean nothing. Micro and Macro cals can be found for a varitiety of reasons. You didnt mention (at least I didnt catch it in your posts) if the microcals seen are seen in some sort of pattern. IE linear or cluster. When they show up in a pattern like that, it is a bit of a flag. IF (and I stress IF) is does come back positive for something, it's far more likely it will be 1)VERY small in size and 2) either DCIS or LCIS, both of which are stage 0, non-invasive cancer and VERY VERY treatable. Keep breathing slow deep breaths. This is the hardest time. DONT BE SEARCHING DR GOOGLE!!. Since you are an educator (and thank you for teaching our children), and feel a need to at least educate yourself on something, I would stick to the topics of DCIS or LCIS. Dont be beyond that and I would do your reseach on this site or credible medical sites. God Bless. Keep yourself busy. Most like it is nothing. Most women who come thru here and have a biopsy on microcals come back with B9 results.....

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 11:53AM - edited Aug 29, 2011 11:57AM by marie5890 (cut and paste of Beesie's post from 2009) The study that you've linked to in your original post was written in 2007 - after your mother's surgery, I would guess.  Within the full report it specifically states that "Studies on the effect of tumor location on prognosis report inconsistent results. Some studies showed higher risks of death from breast cancer in patients with tumors of the inner quadrants, or inner quadrants plus central portion of the breast, or lower quadrants, or all quadrants except the upper-outer quadrant,whereas other studies showed no association whatsoever between tumor location and breast cancer prognosis."  So obviously there were no conclusive findings at the time of your mother's diagnosis. Even looking at the details of the study, there are a few other things that stick out to me: As for the results themselves, this study is by no means suggesting that everyone who had a lower inner quadrant cancer is going to get mets.  Here are the 10 year survival rates from the study: So yes, there is a "statistically significant" difference in the results, and a 12% mortality rate is not good.  But 88% of the women with lower inner quadrant Stage I BC were alive after 10 years. Lastly, about what scans are given upon diagnosis, the NCCN treatment guidelines for physicians are the guidelines followed by most doctors in North America.  These are updated every year.  The 2009 edition indicates that for Stage I, bone scans and CT scans are optional, required only if symptoms indicate a need.  See page 9: http://www.nccn.org/professionals/physician_gls/PDF/breast.pdfs I don't mean to downplay anyone's concerns and I agree that it's important to understand our diagnoses and the implications of our diagnoses.  But we also have to realize that new information becomes available every day and a study that is released one day might be contradicted by another study the next day.  There is no point in becoming fearful because of one study, where the authors themselves admit that the analysis is not as complete as they would want.    EDITED TO ADD:  In reading the couple of posts after mine, I just want to clarify that I'm not suggesting that anyone who has symptoms or reasons for concern ignore those things and not seek all the tests and treatments.  I'm just saying that if you don't have reasons for concern, don't let a study like the one above make you worry.  If everyone of us scoured the internet we could all find studies that say that our specific diagnosis is particularly bad for some reason or another.

Posts.Content: Dec 19, 2011 09:53PM marie5890 wrote: Hello Karen and welcome.  Take a deep breath. Seriously.  The reason that the radiologist is recommending a biospy is because he cant by his experience and training, really determine what, if anything, that two areas are about. Get that "doesnt bode well" thought out of your mind. That isnt the case at all.  It just means he really cant tell and it would be wise to get a definitive answer thru biopsy. Remember, biopsies more often than not (up to 80%) come back B9 as well. But he is being a causious doctor, as he should be. He isnt saying that they are cancer. What he is saying is he doesnt know. Really, try your best to have a nice holiday. Dont go doing any research, it wont help. If anything it will just scare you.

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2012 11:18AM - edited Jan 28, 2012 11:20AM by marie5890 Good luck Druanne!, Guineamom, yes they can only biopsy what they can see. If he couldnt seen one of the lesions while doing the biopsy, he couldnt biopsy it. My guess is that when you go to the BS the BS may have a couple of options. 1) would be to biopsy the second lesion with a wire guided biopsy. 2)or and MRI guided biopsy or 3)waiting 3-6 months and watching it. For me, I went for a US guided core biopsy and they couldnt find it either so that attempt at a biopsy at that time was a bust. But it did show up on mammo and MRI. So I ended up having  a stereotactic biopsy.   Im guessing it will depend on how concerned the BS is. Good luck to you too

Posts.Content: Jun 6, 2011 07:55PM marie5890 wrote: Kasi, I am sorry that the results were positive.  A couple of things. First, if the anxiety gets a bit overwhelming, BREATHE. Seriously. Take slow deep breathes. 2nd..and this is important. Dont get ahead of yourself and where you are at right now. If you are reading the various forums on this board, try and stay within those threads that the most closely align with where you are at. "Breast Cancer" isn't one disease. It's a boat load of all kinds of different cancers. Each unique so how it is treated depends on the "personality" of the kind you have.  It's going to take a bit of time to find out exactly what kind YOU have.  In the "Just diagnosed" section, you will see a "sticky thread" of "Just Diagnosed: Get prepared" It will give you practical steps you can take to make you feel a bit more in control It's not uncommon when first diagnosed to feel like the rug of life has been ripped out from underneath you and feel out of control. These practical steps will help aid in giving you control back. You have found a great site with ladies who have walked this walk. They will hug you, scream with you, rant with and for you, cry with you, laugh with you, encourage and uplift you. You are so not alone. Not by a long shot. Many have walked and are walking this journey. 3rd. GET COPIES OF ALL YOUR REPORTS! Pathology, radiology etc etc. The women here can help you discipher them if you would like. 4th. If you have the (very common) thought of "this is a death sentence", just toss it out the window. It is cancer, yes, but now a days the survival rate of BC is quite high, esp here in the USA because tends to be caught early. Even in young women.

Just be careful you arent feeding imagination/worry bucket. And I know that is a hard line to find. God Bless.We all know how hard it is

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2014 01:02PM marie5890 wrote: Calcs can come and go. There are many reasons why calks happen. Having extreme dense breast does not raise your chance of cancer, but it can make it harder to detect w/imaging. In my state of CT, a woman who has extremely dense breast tissue (>75%) can not be denied a MRI as MRI can get a better look. If calcs are the only thing present on imaging and it is cancer, generally that is early cancer, but that is only a general observation. How early stage breast cancer is treated really depends more the kind it is. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term. If its something like DCIS or LCIS is surgically removed, often times with radiation and perhaps something like tomaxophin.  Daf, I am sorry this is one more concern on your life's plate. Praying that the calcs are not a flag of something bigger going on. Hope this hurdle turns out to be nothing and that you can get a transplant. Prayers and God bless….

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2017 02:58PM marie5890 wrote: Concerned, I think part of the problem is that you have the idea that Architectural Distortion will show up on an MRI. It won't. It's just a distortion that shows up on a mammogram and a closer look is needed to see what is causing that distortion. It basically means something is showing up a distortion. All of the three diffenent imaging for breasts, (mammo, US, MRI) will pick up different things. For example, microcals and architectural distortion will not be picked up by a MRI. MRIs are looking for blood flow, and not just in general, but pick up and wash out. Remember this when you read your reports or anything online. You don't have the education that the radiologists (who are doctors with specialized focus in radiology) so you really won't understand what you are reading without some guidance. I think that is where a great deal of your confusion is coming in. Most women will end up having a biopsy or so after awhile. That doesn't mean they have cancer. It's just that many things happen to our breasts, especially as we age and hormones change, and a biopsy will be asked for to see "what is going on". Changes are typical. I do think Michelle gave you some great advice if you believe you have been harmed. I hear that your head is spinning and that your anxiety is going thru the roof. Just keep reminding yourself that you don't have cancer. it may help keep your thoughts from spinning circles it seems to be caught up in. If you are having a hard time sleeping, perhaps you can talk to your primary about getting some anti-anxiety meds to help you until all of this clears up.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2016 12:30AM marie5890 wrote: Elizabeth you are right. Mammo's or U/S are not fool proof. ( I've even seen a couple of women here where an MRI didn't pick up their cancer, but that is far more rare) Different imaging techniques pick up different things. For example in my state (CT) if a woman's mammo shows that she has extremely dense breast tissue (>75%), by state law, her insurance company cannot turn down a doctor's order for an MRI. That is because mammos don't do well with dense breast tissue (and why mammos are not ordered all that much for younger women. they can be pretty useless)

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2014 04:27PM marie5890 wrote: Ally, hello and welcome. I hear your fear and anxiety. Do those who have a BIRAD 5 ever have it come back as not cancer? Yes, that does happen from time to time. But more often than not, it is cancer. So hope you are one of those who do get a B9 result, yet, as far as possible, try to mentally prepare for it to be cancer. I know that really isn't truly possible, but its highly likely you have BC. So take a deep breath. Take several. Don't do any research yet. "Breast cancer" is an umbrella term, and if it does come back as cancer, it will take some time to know what kind YOU have. Get a prescript for an anti-axniety med. The beginning of this journey is hard because of the unknown. Anything that helps keep you somewhat level headed will be helpful. If you feel like you need to be doing something, start with the main page of BCO, and under the diagnosis tab, you will begin to learn some of the medical-eze that you will hear ("stage""grade" "type" "hormonal receptors" etc… prayers Ally. I know you feel like you just got blow out of the water and kicked in the gut at the same time

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2011 10:59AM marie5890 wrote: Hi Murph and welcome, Should you be concerned? The answer to that is there is something there that needs to be checked out. The only way to really know what is causing the shadowing is to biopsy it. From that you wrote, even the radiologist can't say even with their expertise. That is why they need a biopsy.  Read my signature. There was something there. They couldn't tell just by looking at the films (I had mammos, Ultrasound and and MRI) A biopsy showed that it was a benign tumor. That is what your reports is in essence saying. "There is something there; we dont know what it is" Again back to your question: How nervous should you be?  I would say, try not to be nervous, but this does need to be check out. This part is always the hardest, the "not knowing". Do you best to keep your self busy and dont do too much research on it. There simply is not enough information for you to go on at this point and all that research will most likely do is scare you. If you feel a need to check around here, try your best to stay only with those threads that really represent where you are at. Most threads here don't really apply to you at this point. No need to fuel anxiety Ask any questions you need to though!!
